title: Georgia House - Day 22 (2026-02-16)
summary:
Overview:
The Georgia House session on February 16, 2026 involved several key legislative actions, including the introduction of new bills and discussion of substantive legislation.

Key Actions:
- **HB 52**: Bill passed
- **HB 872**: Bill referred to committee
- **SB 353**: Bill introduced

Bills Introduced (First Reading):
- SB 353

Notable Moments:
- Opening prayer and remarks by Pastor Sherrin Jack, highlighting the need for wisdom and humility in governing.
- Recognition of the "Doctor of the Day", Dr. Jeffrey Cooper.
- Quote from Chairman Tarvan: "No one has ever become poor by giving."

Votes:
- HB 52 passed
- Other votes not explicitly mentioned

Attendance:
- Quorum present, all members voted to signify their presence.

Adjournment:
The session adjourned to reconvene at a later date.

As is our custom, we will begin our day with scripture reading in prayer by the chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Our chaplain this morning will be introduced by the lady from the 60th House District, representing Sheila Jones, who is in her 20th year in this body. Appreciate her service. Representative Jones. Thank you, Mr. Speaker and members of the House. Our chaplain for the day is Pastor Sherrin Jack, the senior pastor of Barand's 7th day Adventist Church in Atlanta. Pastor Jack is married to the former Patricia Johnson, a little rock Arkansas, and she serves as an educator in Decap County. Together, they have one daughter, Elise, who is currently attending Oakwood University. He is joined today by Anthony and Helen Murphy of Barand Church. Will you both stand as we welcome you to the House of Representatives? Pastor Jack was born in Trinidad at an early age, his family moved to Brooklyn, New York. Pastor Jack has been in ministry for over 30 years. He has ministered in several countries across the globe and has been instrumental in establishing five churches in the United States. He has trained several interns and conducted workshops and seminars for pastors in several countries. Let us welcome and hear from our chaplain of the day, Pastor Sherrin Jack. Thank you, Mr. Speaker and to the members of this body for affording us this opportunity to be here this morning to just share a word of encouragement to each and every one of you as you embark upon, I believe, a most sacred and responsible task in governing our state. Join me in prayer this time, will you? Dear God, make us wise that we will recognize our limitations and acknowledge our inadequacies for the awesome task of leading this great people of our state. Make us wise so that we will walk in humility and seek your wisdom to lead as we are being led. Grant unto us a compassionate heart that we will always seek to do that which will be for your glory and for our mutual good. Grant unto us a compassionate govern that we will one day hear from your voice declaring well done, thou good and faithful servant is our prayer in your holy name. Amen. Thank you. I will not be long this morning. I just have a few words of encouragement for us today. And I've entitled the brief devotion, a prayer for wisdom. The text that I will reference this morning is found in 1 Kings chapter 3 looking at verses 1 through 5. One night God appeared to Solomon in a dream and said, ask for whatever you want me to give you. Solomon responded in a way that to God that reflected both his knowledge and his appreciation of how God had dealt with his father David. And how much he needed God's help now that the weight of responsibility for leading God's people now rested squarely upon him. He understood that leadership carries both the privilege and responsibility. And he knew that it was only with God's help that he would be able to carry out his duties as King. In verse 9 of the same chapter 1 Kings chapter 3, Solomon asked God for wisdom. Wisdom, so God gave, so God gave your servant wisdom and a discerning heart to govern your people and to distinguish between right and wrong. For who is able to govern this great people? God was pleased with Solomon's requests and responded by saying, since you have not asked for long life or wealth, no have you asked for the death of your enemies but for discernment in administering justice? I will do what you ask. I will give you a wise at discerning heart so that you will never be alone, be anyone like you, both in the past and in the future. Moreover, I will give you what you have not asked for, both wealth and honor, so that in your lifetime there will be no equal among kings. And if you walk in obedience to me and keep my decrees and commands, as David your father did, I will give you long life. Just a couple of lessons that I think that will be helpful to us and be a source of encouragement to us as we carry out or duties today. Three lessons from this brief interaction. Number one, humility. Humility is a recognition and affirmation that God is fully aware of what we need in order to carry out His will. Secondly, obedience. Obedience to God's Word will ultimately work for His glory and for our mutual good. Sacrifice. A willingness to give up our plans to fulfill the purposes of God. Often we will be called to stand, even when we don't understand, but by God's grace and might and power, He will enable us to withstand. The Bible tells us that Solomon was a wise man and God blessed him tremendously. He wasn't perfect, but he had a heart that was open to the leading of God's grace and open to receiving the mercy of God. In the very last chapter of the book, I'll be clasiascities. There's a summation of Solomon's collective wisdom and experience expressed in verse 13. And I'll leave that with you this morning. Here's what he says. Let us hear the conclusion of the whole matter. Fear God. Keep His commandments for therein lies the whole duty of man. As God has placed you in a position of leadership to set parameters, laws, and guidelines for us, the citizenry of this great state of Georgia. My prayer this morning is that each and every one of you will spend a moment of silent, personal, preferable reflection so that the same God that led Solomon and the same God that imparted wisdom and insight and knowledge to Solomon will impart wisdom, knowledge, and insight to you. And that as you collectively lead, you will be led by God who is all-knowing and who is all-wise. May God grant you His peace in this most sacred and most awesome responsibility to provide a climate in which all of us as citizens can live out of full potential and be all that God will have us to be. May God's blessing be upon you all. And thank you for the opportunity to share this morning. Thank you. I'm trying to play this place. The members, I bring to you House Bill 546, the Pharmacy Adaptation Act. This is a common sense bill. I believe you'll agree with me when I get through. I'm very honored to do the occasional pharmacy bill because my dad was a pharmacist back in the old days when they called him Doc Jasper's. And we were very proud of that. So how many of y'all been to an emergency room? The doctor's office or unfortunately maybe an emergency clinic? And they prescribed a drug to help you get through the day or night or a few days. Going to the pharmacy and they don't have the exact thing. They've got the same thing but they don't have the exact thing. And now you have to go somewhere on a little trip to try to find that exact prescription medicine. What this bill will do will help you with that problem. So you go to the clinic and they prescribe a 500 milligram antibiotic, whatever, eight of them, the description of how to use it. You go to your pharmacy but they're out of the 500s. This will allow them with your permission, in the physician's permission, to do a 250 milligram, 16 of them, with the directions and label how you're to appropriately take them. That's easy, common sense. The second thing it will do is that the pharmacist will be allowed to adjust the prescription from maintenance drug. Now many, many people take maintenance medication every day. And you know if you do that, your pharmacy or the prescription benefit plan or whoever, the pharmacy is moving to 90 day prescriptions, save you a trip, save them work also. That's been the trend. This will allow the pharmacist to adapt the prescription to fit that 90 day regime. It's very helpful. I think you'll agree. There's some common sense safeguards this bill. If the physician were to happen to write on it, no substitutions or changes made, there could be nothing done. You have to ask the patient, is it okay? Okay, that's good. And then the pharmacist has to make a record in their medical record that they've done this and documented, so all can see. It's very common sense, very consumer friendly. Representative Bickey Evans is recognized for and afternoon order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Colleagues, I wanted to bring attention to the flyer on your desk today that's addressed by a pediatric trauma surgeon, Alexis Smith. And for the first time in modern medicine in 2022, firearm injuries surpassed car accidents and childhood cancer as the leading cause of death and children and adolescents. And from 2019 to 2020, firearm related deaths of all types, suicides unintentional among children and adolescents increased 29.5% in two years. An analysis of the data shows that nine in every 100,000 children died from firearm injuries in the state of Georgia every year. And that is 50% more than the national average, which again is six in every 100,000 children. And when you compare that to states with more robust gun laws such as New York or New Jersey, children in Georgia die of firearm injuries at rates 4.5 times that as in New York and New Jersey. And in Europe, no other peer country in Europe has firearm injuries listed among the top five causes of death in children. A child in Georgia dies from firearm injuries at a rate approximately 15 times more than children in Canada and 30 times more than children in France. In recent years, pediatric trauma surgeons in America are seeing a rising number of penetrating injuries from firearms in our pediatric trauma days. This number is rising at alarming rates and is reached levels that are overwhelming our pediatric trauma units. I ask that this body do our part by passing safe gun ownership laws and use our influence in the public to practice and demonstrate safe gun ownership. Thank you. That concludes our afternoon orders.
